segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: 9-9-6 is a phrase used to describe the routine of working from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m., six days a week. This kind of work schedule has become commonplace in China, especially in tech and internet companies, as technopreneurs hope this industrious attitude will translate into business success. However, the dark side of working 9-9-6 came into the spotlight in January 2021, when an employee died while working for e-commerce giant Pinduoduo. But this wasn't the first time 9-9-6 came to public attention. In 2019, an online movement called 996.icu, initiated by Chinese IT practitioners, criticized the practice of 9-9-6 in posts, stating it threatened the health of tech employees. These posts trended online as many tech workers related to the frustrations of overwork. However, many, like Nicole, still cannot escape the grind. Nicole was born in 1992. After getting her master's degree in the UK, she worked 9-9-6 in a tech company in Shenzhen for three years. In 2020, she left this company to work for one of the biggest internet companies in China. But the situation only got worse.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: We returned to the company from 9-9-6. We worked until 9-9-7 in the evening. In the second half of the year, we worked from 11-11-12. We didn't have any rest.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Now I'm a bit numb.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: I don't rest in the second half of the year. I used to talk about the situation in the second half of the year. Now I basically take a shower in the second half of the year. Then I lie down. Then I start playing my phone. I don't know what I'm looking at. I'm just like this, aimlessly. I don't feel anything. My phone is just like this. Then I go to sleep at around 12-12.30 a.m. Then the day ends.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: It was really hard to make an appointment with Nicole due to her packed schedule. She ran one and a half hour late from a business trip in Shanghai, so we had to catch her on a train ride home.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: We had a long meeting today. Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. Yes. And then the schedule itself should be from 3 p.m. to 6 p.m. Yes. But it took almost an hour and a half to start filming. Yes. An hour and a half more. I'm going home. I'm going home. I'm going home. I can chat while I'm at home. We can eat together. Yes, we eat breakfast, lunch, and dinner at the company. And sometimes we eat at the workplace. I'm far from home now. I'm far from home now. If we talk, we can type. Let's go to bed now. Because the changes in this industry are relatively fast, so when you come in after the interview,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02
segments.text: it may be completely different.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: I didn't really think about it, because I didn't say that I might have to deal with some personal matters. Now it may be a matter of life and death. It's still a bit hard. It's still a bit hard.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02
segments.text: I feel that this is why it's so obvious. The reason is that he is under pressure. Mr. Chao Dewang, who opened a glass factory in the United States, observed this phenomenon. He said that compared to China's white-collar workers and the white-collar workers in the United States, China's white-collar workers have a lower income than the white-collar workers in the United States. But the double of the low is much lower than the income level of the blue-collar workers. In the Chinese society, the low-income and the middle-income levels have a big difference. If the middle-income and the middle-income families don't work hard enough, they may fall into the low-income class. In such a situation, everyone is under great pressure. We have to work hard. We must work hard. So we will take the initiative to go to 996.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_04
segments.text: It's more frequent to work here. Frequent.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_08
segments.text: Frequent. The working hours are over. Frequent. We are 995 now.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: Normally... It's not always like this. Maybe one day there is a work task. We have to finish the work task.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_05
segments.text: Working overtime must be tiring.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: I think it's okay.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_05
segments.text: If you work overtime so late every day, you must be happy. If you want to be happy, you must be tired.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Ming is a game operation manager working in Shanghai. In her previous work, Ming faced similar problems to Nicole. After enduring the 996 system for four years, she decided to leave for good in October 2020. Now, Ming's working hours are much healthier and balanced.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_08
segments.text: It's a pity. Why did you choose to sleep here today? The reason I quit was because I really felt that I had reached a limit. If I continued like this, I would feel that my whole body is really bad. Of course, it's not just the pressure of working hours. It's also a kind of psychological torture. 996 is not strictly speaking, which means that I have to work six days a week at 9 p.m. But now it has become a state where I have to be on standby for work at any time. In other words, you may need to work at any time. For example, in my previous work, I often had to get up at 2 or 3 a.m. to answer questions. Even in the latter part of the day, I had a hallucination. I always felt that my phone was ringing. I always felt that someone was looking for me.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Chinese labor law stipulates that employers should not force their employees to work more than eight hours a day or more than 44 hours a week. However, the execution of the law seems ineffective. To avoid legal problems, HR often uses non-fixed working-hour contracts to replace the term 996.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: At that time, when our country made the labor law, it was in 1994. At that time, it stipulated that 8 hours a day, a week, the labor law stipulated that an average of 44 hours of working hours is equal to the salary of a developed country. For example, the salary of the United States, Germany, Japan, and South Korea is equal to 40 hours a day. Now it seems that the salary is relatively high. In this case, it means that when the law enforcement department requires companies to make economic compensations to the workers, the compensation standard is actually relatively high. After the implementation, if the company strictly follows this standard, it will be very... it may really destroy the company if it is strictly implemented.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: In China, work unions are not independent organizations formed freely by employees, and work unions established without government approval are illegal. Due to the complications of these labor laws and the difficulty of establishing unions, it is hard to protect the rights and interests of workers.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: The work of the unions is the same as the work of the workers, so there must be some unsuitable places. But as a worker, you have to make a living, so you have to work.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_08
segments.text: What supports me? First of all, it is definitely a fairly high salary, because indeed, if you change jobs, there is no other job that can be paid like this. And secondly, because the people around me are all living the same life as me, There's a sense of unwillingness. If others can hold on, why can't I? Now I've thought about it. I want to live a happy life. If that's my goal, I don't think I can live a happy life like I used to. So I decided to be better for myself.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Ming now has a better work-life balance. She works from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. with a two-hour lunch break, five days a week.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_08
segments.text: I'm very satisfied with my current life. The most important thing about a new job is that you don't have to work overtime. The bosses are very casual. My colleagues are also people who pay more attention to work and life balance. In this environment, I feel relaxed.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: In a snub to China's rat race and expectation to work long hours, Generation Z are calling on their peers to start slacking off, or as they have dubbed it, 摸鱼, or touching fish. This philosophy of touching fish is borrowed from a Chinese proverb which states, Muddy waters make it easy to catch fish. It means that people should take advantage of a crisis to chase personal gains.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_08
segments.text: If there were no other urgent matters, I would go downstairs to catch a fish with my colleagues, buy a cup of coffee, and look at the scenery outside. Of course, you don't dare to leave the workplace for too long. What if the boss wants to find you but you can't find anyone? It's better to say that catching fish should be the only pleasure for the workers. It's really about occasionally catching fish for the whole day.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: While many have critical opinions against 996, some see it as an inevitable sacrifice for success in China. In a post on Alibaba's WeChat account, leading tech titan Jack Ma famously stated, I personally think that being able to work 996 is a huge blessing. In another post on Weibo, he also wrote that he won't defend 996, but he salutes those who are willing to work hard to improve their livelihoods. Li Ran works in a web media company in Beijing as a manager, leading a team of 20 people. She believes that if you feel there's no way to escape, you should work harder instead of complaining.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_06
segments.text: From a certain point of view, it's hard to avoid. If you don't do it, the Chinese will do it. And from the company's point of view, it's the same. If you don't work overtime, and the other companies are working overtime, then your company's cost will increase, your efficiency will decrease, and you will be criticized by others. Sometimes, it may not be something that we actively choose, but because people around you are moving forward, you don't dare to stop. Even if I change a company, or change a place, it may still be the same result. Maybe there is no report yet. I have achieved a certain result now, or the company has given me a certain response, because I chose to persist at that time. And the friends who didn't persist also left this team. So, in fact, I really think that sometimes, what kind of life you are living now is caused by the countless choices you made in the past. I think everyone may be

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_08
segments.text: passive in this strange circle of 996. Because, first of all, others are in 996. You can't be not 996. Because you don't want to be 996. Because you don't want to be the person who is lazy, or the person who is not good in the eyes of the boss, and likes to be lazy. Second, even if you are the boss, I think they may be helpless. Because our business, the demand for performance is indeed very high. To achieve the demand for performance, you have to use so many workers and people to fill it up. In fact, I think everyone has not many choices.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02
segments.text: Because compared to China and Western countries, our culture is still a little different. Our culture is dignified and superior. We have to be the superior of people. What is the superior of people? It means that you are dignified and superior. Of course, we hope that in the end, we can follow the view of equality. That is, we are all in the middle class.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_07
segments.text: What is inevitable is not necessarily reasonable, nor is it necessarily legal. As a person, I think the most important thing is the liberation of humanity. There is also a development concept based on human beings. I think these things are the most fundamental things that continue to develop in the long run.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: The philosophy and practice of 996 is complex. Most of the employees that we interviewed evidently knew that they were sacrificing their physical and mental health, but they still persevere. Heavy stress is weighing on young employees in China due to the immense pressure they place on themselves to improve their economic position and social status. There is hope for change as some companies begin to acknowledge the extremity of 996 and offer fairer working hours to their employees. However, although 996 has been brought to the public's attention and has been criticized for many years, their practice continues.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: I'm not too tired today. I got off work at 5 o'clock today,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_04
segments.text: and then we went to the group meeting. And then...

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: I saw the band that I like, and it was pretty good. But I should be tired tomorrow, because I have a meeting early tomorrow morning. I should have finished my work at 10 o'clock.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_04
segments.text: And now I have 126 hours. It's almost 10 o'clock.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: For my current state, I really don't have much life. And I don't think I have much soul. I'm rather numb, including... I used to... I used to feel like my heart wasn't that heavy every day. I used to feel like when I got off work, I was just a little bit tired.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_06
segments.text: But now I feel like

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03
segments.text: I'm falling asleep. That's how I feel.
